scene-body.stagedir: Enter a Sergeant of a band with two Sentinels

speech.speaker: Sergeant
speech.line: Sirs, take your places and be vigilant:
If any noise or soldier you perceive
Near to the walls, by some apparent sign
Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.

speech.speaker: First Sentinel
speech.line: Sergeant, you shall.
Thus are poor servitors,
When others sleep upon their quiet beds,
Constrain'd to watch in darkness, rain and cold.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, and Forces, with scaling-ladders, their drums beating a dead march

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy,
By whose approach the regions of Artois,
Wallon and Picardy are friends to us,
This happy night the Frenchmen are secure,
Having all day caroused and banqueted:
Embrace we then this opportunity
As fitting best to quittance their deceit
Contrived by art and baleful sorcery.

speech.speaker: BEDFORD
speech.line: Coward of France! how much he wrongs his fame,
Despairing of his own arm's fortitude,
To join with witches and the help of hell!

speech.speaker: BURGUNDY
speech.line: Traitors have never other company.
But what's that Pucelle whom they term so pure?

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: A maid, they say.

speech.speaker: BEDFORD
speech.line: A maid! and be so martial!

speech.speaker: BURGUNDY
speech.line: Pray God she prove not masculine ere long,
If underneath the standard of the French
She carry armour as she hath begun.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Well, let them practise and converse with spirits:
God is our fortress, in whose conquering name
Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.

speech.speaker: BEDFORD
speech.line: Ascend, brave Talbot; we will follow thee.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Not all together: better far, I guess,
That we do make our entrance several ways;
That, if it chance the one of us do fail,
The other yet may rise against their force.

speech.speaker: BEDFORD
speech.line: Agreed: I'll to yond corner.

speech.speaker: BURGUNDY
speech.line: And I to this.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: And here will Talbot mount, or make his grave.
Now, Salisbury, for thee, and for the right
Of English Henry, shall this night appear
How much in duty I am bound to both.

speech.speaker: Sentinels
speech.line: Arm! arm! the enemy doth make assault!

scene-body.stagedir: The French leap over the walls in their shirts. Enter, several ways, the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, and REIGNIER, half ready, and half unready

speech.speaker: ALENCON
speech.line: How now, my lords! what, all unready so?

speech.speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
speech.line: Unready! ay, and glad we 'scaped so well.

speech.speaker: REIGNIER
speech.line: 'Twas time, I trow, to wake and leave our beds,
Hearing alarums at our chamber-doors.

speech.speaker: ALENCON
speech.line: Of all exploits since first I follow'd arms,
Ne'er heard I of a warlike enterprise
More venturous or desperate than this.

speech.speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
speech.line: I think this Talbot be a fiend of hell.

speech.speaker: REIGNIER
speech.line: If not of hell, the heavens, sure, favour him.

speech.speaker: ALENCON
speech.line: Here cometh Charles: I marvel how he sped.

speech.speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
speech.line: Tut, holy Joan was his defensive guard.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter CHARLES and JOAN LA PUCELLE

speech.speaker: CHARLES
speech.line: Is this thy cunning, thou deceitful dame?
Didst thou at first, to flatter us withal,
Make us partakers of a little gain,
That now our loss might be ten times so much?

speech.speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speech.line: Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend!
At all times will you have my power alike?
Sleeping or waking must I still prevail,
Or will you blame and lay the fault on me?
Improvident soldiers! had your watch been good,
This sudden mischief never could have fall'n.

speech.speaker: CHARLES
speech.line: Duke of Alencon, this was your default,
That, being captain of the watch to-night,
Did look no better to that weighty charge.

speech.speaker: ALENCON
speech.line: Had all your quarters been as safely kept
As that whereof I had the government,
We had not been thus shamefully surprised.

speech.speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
speech.line: Mine was secure.

speech.speaker: REIGNIER
speech.line: And so was mine, my lord.

speech.speaker: CHARLES
speech.line: And, for myself, most part of all this night,
Within her quarter and mine own precinct
I was employ'd in passing to and fro,
About relieving of the sentinels:
Then how or which way should they first break in?

speech.speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
speech.line: Question, my lords, no further of the case,
How or which way: 'tis sure they found some place
But weakly guarded, where the breach was made.
And now there rests no other shift but this;
To gather our soldiers, scatter'd and dispersed,
And lay new platforms to endamage them.

scene-body.stagedir: Alarum. Enter an English Soldier, crying 'A Talbot! a Talbot!' They fly, leaving their clothes behind

speech.speaker: Soldier
speech.line: I'll be so bold to take what they have left.
The cry of Talbot serves me for a sword;
For I have loaden me with many spoils,
Using no other weapon but his name.

scene.title: SCENE II. Orleans. Within the town.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter TALBOT, BEDFORD, BURGUNDY, a Captain, and others

speech.speaker: BEDFORD
speech.line: The day begins to break, and night is fled,
Whose pitchy mantle over-veil'd the earth.
Here sound retreat, and cease our hot pursuit.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Bring forth the body of old Salisbury,
And here advance it in the market-place,
The middle centre of this cursed town.
Now have I paid my vow unto his soul;
For every drop of blood was drawn from him,
There hath at least five Frenchmen died tonight.
And that hereafter ages may behold
What ruin happen'd in revenge of him,
Within their chiefest temple I'll erect
A tomb, wherein his corpse shall be interr'd:
Upon the which, that every one may read,
Shall be engraved the sack of Orleans,
The treacherous manner of his mournful death
And what a terror he had been to France.
But, lords, in all our bloody massacre,
I muse we met not with the Dauphin's grace,
His new-come champion, virtuous Joan of Arc,
Nor any of his false confederates.

speech.speaker: BEDFORD
speech.line: 'Tis thought, Lord Talbot, when the fight began,
Roused on the sudden from their drowsy beds,
They did amongst the troops of armed men
Leap o'er the walls for refuge in the field.

speech.speaker: BURGUNDY
speech.line: Myself, as far as I could well discern
For smoke and dusky vapours of the night,
Am sure I scared the Dauphin and his trull,
When arm in arm they both came swiftly running,
Like to a pair of loving turtle-doves
That could not live asunder day or night.
After that things are set in order here,
We'll follow them with all the power we have.

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: All hail, my lords! which of this princely train
Call ye the warlike Talbot, for his acts
So much applauded through the realm of France?

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Here is the Talbot: who would speak with him?

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: The virtuous lady, Countess of Auvergne,
With modesty admiring thy renown,
By me entreats, great lord, thou wouldst vouchsafe
To visit her poor castle where she lies,
That she may boast she hath beheld the man
Whose glory fills the world with loud report.

speech.speaker: BURGUNDY
speech.line: Is it even so? Nay, then, I see our wars
Will turn unto a peaceful comic sport,
When ladies crave to be encounter'd with.
You may not, my lord, despise her gentle suit.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Ne'er trust me then; for when a world of men
Could not prevail with all their oratory,
Yet hath a woman's kindness over-ruled:
And therefore tell her I return great thanks,
And in submission will attend on her.
Will not your honours bear me company?

speech.speaker: BEDFORD
speech.line: No, truly; it is more than manners will:
And I have heard it said, unbidden guests
Are often welcomest when they are gone.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Well then, alone, since there's no remedy,
I mean to prove this lady's courtesy.
Come hither, captain.
You perceive my mind?

speech.speaker: Captain
speech.line: I do, my lord, and mean accordingly.

scene.title: SCENE III. Auvergne. The COUNTESS's castle.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter the COUNTESS and her Porter

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: Porter, remember what I gave in charge;
And when you have done so, bring the keys to me.

speech.speaker: Porter
speech.line: Madam, I will.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: The plot is laid: if all things fall out right,
I shall as famous be by this exploit
As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus' death.
Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight,
And his achievements of no less account:
Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears,
To give their censure of these rare reports.

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: Madam,
According as your ladyship desired,
By message craved, so is Lord Talbot come.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: And he is welcome. What! is this the man?

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: Madam, it is.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: Is this the scourge of France?
Is this the Talbot, so much fear'd abroad
That with his name the mothers still their babes?
I see report is fabulous and false:
I thought I should have seen some Hercules,
A second Hector, for his grim aspect,
And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs.
Alas, this is a child, a silly dwarf!
It cannot be this weak and writhled shrimp
Should strike such terror to his enemies.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Madam, I have been bold to trouble you;
But since your ladyship is not at leisure,
I'll sort some other time to visit you.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: What means he now? Go ask him whither he goes.

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: Stay, my Lord Talbot; for my lady craves
To know the cause of your abrupt departure.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Marry, for that she's in a wrong belief,
I go to certify her Talbot's here.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: If thou be he, then art thou prisoner.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Prisoner! to whom?

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: To me, blood-thirsty lord;
And for that cause I trained thee to my house.
Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me,
For in my gallery thy picture hangs:
But now the substance shall endure the like,
And I will chain these legs and arms of thine,
That hast by tyranny these many years
Wasted our country, slain our citizens
And sent our sons and husbands captivate.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha!

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: Laughest thou, wretch? thy mirth shall turn to moan.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: I laugh to see your ladyship so fond
To think that you have aught but Talbot's shadow
Whereon to practise your severity.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: Why, art not thou the man?

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: I am indeed.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: Then have I substance too.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: No, no, I am but shadow of myself:
You are deceived, my substance is not here;
For what you see is but the smallest part
And least proportion of humanity:
I tell you, madam, were the whole frame here,
It is of such a spacious lofty pitch,
Your roof were not sufficient to contain't.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: This is a riddling merchant for the nonce;
He will be here, and yet he is not here:
How can these contrarieties agree?

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: That will I show you presently.
speech.stagedir: Winds his horn. Drums strike up: a peal of ordnance. Enter soldiers
speech.line: How say you, madam? are you now persuaded
That Talbot is but shadow of himself?
These are his substance, sinews, arms and strength,
With which he yoketh your rebellious necks,
Razeth your cities and subverts your towns
And in a moment makes them desolate.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: Victorious Talbot! pardon my abuse:
I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited
And more than may be gather'd by thy shape.
Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath;
For I am sorry that with reverence
I did not entertain thee as thou art.

speech.speaker: TALBOT
speech.line: Be not dismay'd, fair lady; nor misconstrue
The mind of Talbot, as you did mistake
The outward composition of his body.
What you have done hath not offended me;
Nor other satisfaction do I crave,
But only, with your patience, that we may
Taste of your wine and see what cates you have;
For soldiers' stomachs always serve them well.

speech.speaker: COUNTESS OF AUVERGNE
speech.line: With all my heart, and think me honoured
To feast so great a warrior in my house.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter the Earls of SOMERSET, SUFFOLK, and WARWICK; RICHARD PLANTAGENET, VERNON, and another Lawyer

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Great lords and gentlemen, what means this silence?
Dare no man answer in a case of truth?

speech.speaker: SUFFOLK
speech.line: Within the Temple-hall we were too loud;
The garden here is more convenient.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Then say at once if I maintain'd the truth;
Or else was wrangling Somerset in the error?

speech.speaker: SUFFOLK
speech.line: Faith, I have been a truant in the law,
And never yet could frame my will to it;
And therefore frame the law unto my will.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, between us.

speech.speaker: WARWICK
speech.line: Between two hawks, which flies the higher pitch;
Between two dogs, which hath the deeper mouth;
Between two blades, which bears the better temper:
Between two horses, which doth bear him best;
Between two girls, which hath the merriest eye;
I have perhaps some shallow spirit of judgement;
But in these nice sharp quillets of the law,
Good faith, I am no wiser than a daw.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance:
The truth appears so naked on my side
That any purblind eye may find it out.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: And on my side it is so well apparell'd,
So clear, so shining and so evident
That it will glimmer through a blind man's eye.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Since you are tongue-tied and so loath to speak,
In dumb significants proclaim your thoughts:
Let him that is a true-born gentleman
And stands upon the honour of his birth,
If he suppose that I have pleaded truth,
From off this brier pluck a white rose with me.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Let him that is no coward nor no flatterer,
But dare maintain the party of the truth,
Pluck a red rose from off this thorn with me.

speech.speaker: WARWICK
speech.line: I love no colours, and without all colour
Of base insinuating flattery
I pluck this white rose with Plantagenet.

speech.speaker: SUFFOLK
speech.line: I pluck this red rose with young Somerset
And say withal I think he held the right.

speech.speaker: VERNON
speech.line: Stay, lords and gentlemen, and pluck no more,
Till you conclude that he upon whose side
The fewest roses are cropp'd from the tree
Shall yield the other in the right opinion.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Good Master Vernon, it is well objected:
If I have fewest, I subscribe in silence.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: And I.

speech.speaker: VERNON
speech.line: Then for the truth and plainness of the case.
I pluck this pale and maiden blossom here,
Giving my verdict on the white rose side.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Prick not your finger as you pluck it off,
Lest bleeding you do paint the white rose red
And fall on my side so, against your will.

speech.speaker: VERNON
speech.line: If I my lord, for my opinion bleed,
Opinion shall be surgeon to my hurt
And keep me on the side where still I am.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Well, well, come on: who else?

speech.speaker: Lawyer
speech.line: Unless my study and my books be false,
The argument you held was wrong in you:
In sign whereof I pluck a white rose too.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Now, Somerset, where is your argument?

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Here in my scabbard, meditating that
Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Meantime your cheeks do counterfeit our roses;
For pale they look with fear, as witnessing
The truth on our side.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: No, Plantagenet,
'Tis not for fear but anger that thy cheeks
Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses,
And yet thy tongue will not confess thy error.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset?

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet?

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth;
Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Well, I'll find friends to wear my bleeding roses,
That shall maintain what I have said is true,
Where false Plantagenet dare not be seen.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Now, by this maiden blossom in my hand,
I scorn thee and thy fashion, peevish boy.

speech.speaker: SUFFOLK
speech.line: Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Proud Pole, I will, and scorn both him and thee.

speech.speaker: SUFFOLK
speech.line: I'll turn my part thereof into thy throat.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Away, away, good William de la Pole!
We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.

speech.speaker: WARWICK
speech.line: Now, by God's will, thou wrong'st him, Somerset;
His grandfather was Lionel Duke of Clarence,
Third son to the third Edward King of England:
Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root?

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: He bears him on the place's privilege,
Or durst not, for his craven heart, say thus.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: By him that made me, I'll maintain my words
On any plot of ground in Christendom.
Was not thy father, Richard Earl of Cambridge,
For treason executed in our late king's days?
And, by his treason, stand'st not thou attainted,
Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry?
His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood;
And, till thou be restored, thou art a yeoman.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: My father was attached, not attainted,
Condemn'd to die for treason, but no traitor;
And that I'll prove on better men than Somerset,
Were growing time once ripen'd to my will.
For your partaker Pole and you yourself,
I'll note you in my book of memory,
To scourge you for this apprehension:
Look to it well and say you are well warn'd.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Ah, thou shalt find us ready for thee still;
And know us by these colours for thy foes,
For these my friends in spite of thee shall wear.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose,
As cognizance of my blood-drinking hate,
Will I for ever and my faction wear,
Until it wither with me to my grave
Or flourish to the height of my degree.

speech.speaker: SUFFOLK
speech.line: Go forward and be choked with thy ambition!
And so farewell until I meet thee next.

speech.speaker: SOMERSET
speech.line: Have with thee, Pole. Farewell, ambitious Richard.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: How I am braved and must perforce endure it!

speech.speaker: WARWICK
speech.line: This blot that they object against your house
Shall be wiped out in the next parliament
Call'd for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester;
And if thou be not then created York,
I will not live to be accounted Warwick.
Meantime, in signal of my love to thee,
Against proud Somerset and William Pole,
Will I upon thy party wear this rose:
And here I prophesy: this brawl to-day,
Grown to this faction in the Temple-garden,
Shall send between the red rose and the white
A thousand souls to death and deadly night.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Good Master Vernon, I am bound to you,
That you on my behalf would pluck a flower.

speech.speaker: VERNON
speech.line: In your behalf still will I wear the same.

speech.speaker: Lawyer
speech.line: And so will I.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Thanks, gentle sir.
Come, let us four to dinner: I dare say
This quarrel will drink blood another day.

scene.title: SCENE V. The Tower of London.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter MORTIMER, brought in a chair, and Gaolers

speech.speaker: MORTIMER
speech.line: Kind keepers of my weak decaying age,
Let dying Mortimer here rest himself.
Even like a man new haled from the rack,
So fare my limbs with long imprisonment.
And these grey locks, the pursuivants of death,
Nestor-like aged in an age of care,
Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer.
These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent,
Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent;
Weak shoulders, overborne with burthening grief,
And pithless arms, like to a wither'd vine
That droops his sapless branches to the ground;
Yet are these feet, whose strengthless stay is numb,
Unable to support this lump of clay,
Swift-winged with desire to get a grave,
As witting I no other comfort have.
But tell me, keeper, will my nephew come?

speech.speaker: First Gaoler
speech.line: Richard Plantagenet, my lord, will come:
We sent unto the Temple, unto his chamber;
And answer was return'd that he will come.

speech.speaker: MORTIMER
speech.line: Enough: my soul shall then be satisfied.
Poor gentleman! his wrong doth equal mine.
Since Henry Monmouth first began to reign,
Before whose glory I was great in arms,
This loathsome sequestration have I had:
And even since then hath Richard been obscured,
Deprived of honour and inheritance.
But now the arbitrator of despairs,
Just death, kind umpire of men's miseries,
With sweet enlargement doth dismiss me hence:
I would his troubles likewise were expired,
That so he might recover what was lost.

speech.speaker: First Gaoler
speech.line: My lord, your loving nephew now is come.

speech.speaker: MORTIMER
speech.line: Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Ay, noble uncle, thus ignobly used,
Your nephew, late despised Richard, comes.

speech.speaker: MORTIMER
speech.line: Direct mine arms I may embrace his neck,
And in his bosom spend my latter gasp:
O, tell me when my lips do touch his cheeks,
That I may kindly give one fainting kiss.
And now declare, sweet stem from York's great stock,
Why didst thou say, of late thou wert despised?

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: First, lean thine aged back against mine arm;
And, in that ease, I'll tell thee my disease.
This day, in argument upon a case,
Some words there grew 'twixt Somerset and me;
Among which terms he used his lavish tongue
And did upbraid me with my father's death:
Which obloquy set bars before my tongue,
Else with the like I had requited him.
Therefore, good uncle, for my father's sake,
In honour of a true Plantagenet
And for alliance sake, declare the cause
My father, Earl of Cambridge, lost his head.

speech.speaker: MORTIMER
speech.line: That cause, fair nephew, that imprison'd me
And hath detain'd me all my flowering youth
Within a loathsome dungeon, there to pine,
Was cursed instrument of his decease.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Discover more at large what cause that was,
For I am ignorant and cannot guess.

speech.speaker: MORTIMER
speech.line: I will, if that my fading breath permit
And death approach not ere my tale be done.
Henry the Fourth, grandfather to this king,
Deposed his nephew Richard, Edward's son,
The first-begotten and the lawful heir,
Of Edward king, the third of that descent:
During whose reign the Percies of the north,
Finding his usurpation most unjust,
Endeavor'd my advancement to the throne:
The reason moved these warlike lords to this
Was, for that--young King Richard thus removed,
Leaving no heir begotten of his body--
I was the next by birth and parentage;
For by my mother I derived am
From Lionel Duke of Clarence, the third son
To King Edward the Third; whereas he
From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigree,
Being but fourth of that heroic line.
But mark: as in this haughty attempt
They laboured to plant the rightful heir,
I lost my liberty and they their lives.
Long after this, when Henry the Fifth,
Succeeding his father Bolingbroke, did reign,
Thy father, Earl of Cambridge, then derived
From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of York,
Marrying my sister that thy mother was,
Again in pity of my hard distress
Levied an army, weening to redeem
And have install'd me in the diadem:
But, as the rest, so fell that noble earl
And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers,
In whom the tide rested, were suppress'd.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Of which, my lord, your honour is the last.

speech.speaker: MORTIMER
speech.line: True; and thou seest that I no issue have
And that my fainting words do warrant death;
Thou art my heir; the rest I wish thee gather:
But yet be wary in thy studious care.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: Thy grave admonishments prevail with me:
But yet, methinks, my father's execution
Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.

speech.speaker: MORTIMER
speech.line: With silence, nephew, be thou politic:
Strong-fixed is the house of Lancaster,
And like a mountain, not to be removed.
But now thy uncle is removing hence:
As princes do their courts, when they are cloy'd
With long continuance in a settled place.

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: O, uncle, would some part of my young years
Might but redeem the passage of your age!

speech.speaker: MORTIMER
speech.line: Thou dost then wrong me, as that slaughterer doth
Which giveth many wounds when one will kill.
Mourn not, except thou sorrow for my good;
Only give order for my funeral:
And so farewell, and fair be all thy hopes
And prosperous be thy life in peace and war!

speech.speaker: RICHARD PLANTAGENET
speech.line: And peace, no war, befall thy parting soul!
In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage
And like a hermit overpass'd thy days.
Well, I will lock his counsel in my breast;
And what I do imagine let that rest.
Keepers, convey him hence, and I myself
Will see his burial better than his life.
speech.stagedir: Exeunt Gaolers, bearing out the body of MORTIMER
speech.line: Here dies the dusky torch of Mortimer,
Choked with ambition of the meaner sort:
And for those wrongs, those bitter injuries,
Which Somerset hath offer'd to my house:
I doubt not but with honour to redress;
And therefore haste I to the parliament,
Either to be restored to my blood,
Or make my ill the advantage of my good.
